Owing to the necessity for the PrimeMinister to be at the railway btat Ion duringQuestion Time on Thursday, June 35th, to meet a Japanese Royal Prince who is paying an officialvisit to this country, the Cabinet agreed (a) That the Prime Minister shouldmake a statement with regard to parliamentary Business in theHouse of Commons the same afternoon:(b) That the Parliamentary Secretaryto the Treasury should be askedto make all arrangements forthis .(NOTE: The Secretary of State forForeign Affairs left theCabinet for a few minutesto communicate with theParliamentary Secretary tothe Treasury.) 2. The Cabinet had under consideration aMemorandum by the Secretary of State for India(C.P.-214 (SO)) which had been before them attheir previous Meeting, and examined paragraph b/paragraph the proposed Statement to be made by thPrime Minister or Secretary of State for India.appended to that Memorandum.In the course of the discussion the following suggestions for amendments in the Statement weremade for the consideration of the Secretary ofState for India:-Paragraph 1. Line 12.For the word "it", put "them".Paragraph 2.First sentence: That the Secretaryof State should consider whetherit might be desirable to introducewords to show that the conference was an evolution from a plan decided on at a much earlier stage for pro-viding some means o^ ascertainingIndian opinion, which had contained the germ of the present scheme. Heshould also check the accuracy ofthe words "at Sir John Simon'ssugg est ion".Line 7 (of paragraph 2): After thewords "to bear"insert the words"on the problem".Last line of page 1: That the wordingmight be amended from a double negativeinto a direct affirmative in some such manner as follows, namely: to replace the words "that it would not be rightto limit its scope by any terms ofreference more restricted than wereimplied In the Viceroy's statementof 1st Nbve-iber last", by some suchphrase, as:- "that its scope should beas wide as that implied in the Viceroy's,.statement of Ist Novembe"" last" . - " ,Fourth -Line of pag e .2: For" the words-"All-Indian problemsput "All-Indian \.r,rC onst itutiorial.problems".The last word of paragraph 2, namely, -"connote" might with advantage bereplaced by "imply" or "indicate". 01 oCI aLine 5: Par the words "must therefore be"put "is therefore".That the second sub-paragraph of Para-graph 3, beginning "The object of theConference ....." might with advantage be omitted unless the Secretary of state should find on examination that there was some special reason for its retention whichwas not cle^r to the Cabinet.Third sub-paragraph^ lines 1 and S: forthe words "any proposals" put "all pro-posals" .Third sub-paragraph^, line 3; for the words"for the realisation of His Majesty'sGovernment's declared policy" put "forthe realisation of the above policy".Third sub-paragraph., line 5: for theword "provision" put "arrangements".Third sub-paragraph, line, 6: for the words"foreign policy" put "foreign relations.Paragraph 4.Line 4 on page 3: for the word "I" put"His Ma j esty' s Governmentw".Paragraph 5.Line 8: for the words "it may not beimpossible" put "it will be possible".Line 3: For the word "solution" put"solutions" .The Cabinet agreed -(a) That the Secretary of State forIndia should re-examine the draft statement in the light of the- Cabinet discussion, with a viewto making such amendments as he might deem advisable:(b) That he should communicate the amended version of the statement to the "Viceroy, together with anyexplanations as he might deemnecess ary:(c) That the Secretary of State forIndia, either directly or throughthe Prire Minister, should commu-nicatc the revised Statement toMr Baldwin and Mr Lloyd Georgeat the earliest possible moment.The Leaders of the opposition parties, accompanied by anycolleague that each of them mightdesire, should be invited to meetthe Prime Minister and the Secretary of State ^or InsLia todiscuss the draft Statement. Atthis meeting it should be made clear to them that the intentionof His Majesty's Government isto make the Conference a reality,and that it was proposed to useany agreement that might be reached as the basis of a Bill to be intro-duced in Parliament. Further, thatwhile, as the principal means of ascertaining Indian opinion, theConference would take the placeof the original proposal thatIndian representatives should give evidence before a JointCommittee of both Houses, thiswould not preclude Parliamentfrom dealing with the government bill by means of a Joint Committeeif such a procedure should commend itself.
